bufferconfig.notes: Rolling 52-week buffer. Array structure with prepend semantics. Week 2 instance prepended to regimes[0]. Week 1 instance now at regimes[1].

regimes.reportcontext: Week 2 of 2026. Market breadth expansion accelerates (66% above 200d MA), Russell 2000 surges 5.1% weekly. Great Rotation from Mag7 concentration toward Healthcare, Financials, small-caps gaining momentum. Core AI infrastructure resilient (MSFT 0.2%, AMZN 0.4%, GOOG 0.9%); speculative AI repricing (AAPL -4.2%, TSLA timeline delays, NVDA -2.1% valuation reset). Manufacturing contraction enters 10th consecutive month; labor market hiring collapse (50K jobs December). Credit spreads ultra-tight (79 bps IG, 279 bps HY); systemic stress remains low. CPI binary catalyst January 14.

lastmajordatarelease.event: Weekly Market Structure Report + Risk Regime Report + AI/Mag7 Intelligence

intraweekalerts.impactdescription: Highest breadth participation in 3 years. 66% of SP500 above 200d moving average signals healthy rotation out of Mag7 concentration. Russell 2000 up 5.1% this week, equal-weight index hitting fresh all-time highs confirms genuine broad-based participation.

Magnificent Seven average down -0.29% week-over-week while equal-weight S&P 500 up 3.2%. Core AI infrastructure (MSFT, AMZN, GOOG) flat-to-up; speculative AI (AAPL -4.2%, TSLA timeline slippage, NVDA valuation reset) repricing lower. Market discrimination between substance and hype is healthy indicator of regime maturation.

Russell 2000 surged 5.1% this week, up 6% year-to-date despite manufacturing weakness and labor market deterioration. RSI at 66 (approaching overbought 70 but not yet). Signals small-cap rotation is real and driven by fundamentals (cyclical valuations, margin expansion) not technical squeeze.

regime.recessionprobabilitydescription: Moderate recession risk at 21% (down from 22% prior week). Manufacturing weakness (10th consecutive contraction) and labor collapse (50K jobs) offset by breadth expansion, credit stability, and locked capex cycle through 2026. Soft-landing scenario remains 50% probability. Deterioration path 15% (DEFENSIVE). Bearish/Crisis path 10% (requires CPI shock or payroll collapse sustained).

growth.description: Manufacturing sector contracted for 10th consecutive month August 2025 through January 2026. ISM PMI 47.9 December 2025 signals continued economic weakness in industrial production. Production subindex 46.1, New Orders 45.8 (critical weakness), Inventories 45.2. However, services sector remains resilient. Manufacturing weakness is structural but not yet systemic given breadth expansion in equity markets. Tariff uncertainty dominating business sentiment. New export orders broken 10th consecutive month contraction at 46.8. For every positive comment about orders, 1.3 negative sentiment ratio indicates demand caution accelerating. Only Computer Electronic Products reported increased new orders among six largest industries.

keyindicators.name: Production Index
keyindicators.implication: Factory output softening, capacity utilization under pressure

keyindicators.name: New Orders Index
keyindicators.implication: Demand weakness accelerating, tariff uncertainty dominating near-term bookings

keyindicators.name: Inventory Index
keyindicators.implication: Rapid destocking, supply-side pressure or demand panic signaling

keyindicators.name: New Export Orders
keyindicators.implication: 10th consecutive month contraction, global weakness carrying into 2026, tariff concerns damaging order flow

keyindicators.name: Sentiment Ratio Negative
keyindicators.implication: For every positive comment about orders, 1.3 negative comments about uncertainty, tariff costs

drivers: Global manufacturing weakness carrying into 2026 consistent global PMI softness
US export headwinds from trade tensions, tariff expectations creating forward caution
Capital goods cycle turning, capex decisions postponed pending policy clarity on tariffs
Seasonal early-January weakness typical, but magnitude of decline exceeding seasonal norms
risks: Manufacturing contraction accelerates: ISM sustained at 47 or below in Q1 2026 signals recession approaching
ISM breaks below 46 with services follow: Composite PMI breaks below 50 indicates systemic contraction underway
Export collapse deepens: New orders continue 10th+ month contraction, global demand synchronized weakness
supports: Services sector resilience: ISM Services continues above 50 (no data available but historical track record strong during manufacturing troughs)
Labor market resilience offsets manufacturing drag: Unemployment 4.4%, jobless claims 208K subdued, consumer still hiring (though slowly)
Credit markets loose, no deleveraging signals: IG spreads 79 bps, HY spreads 279 bps, zero funding stress

labor.description: Labor market showing signs of softening but not deteriorating. Unemployment rate 4.4% improved from 4.6%, signaling tightness in labor supply and low layoff risk. However, December 2025 non-farm payrolls collapsed to only 50,000 jobs weakest in years, versus 73,000 forecast, representing -23,000 miss. This is the worst monthly hiring since 2020 recession outside of pandemic collapse. 2025 annual average job creation 49,000 per month worst year since 2003 outside of recession. November revised down to 56,000, October revised loss to -173,000. This is a hiring recession level dynamic. Jobless claims 208,000 rising slightly but no surge. Continuing claims 1.914M up. Wage growth 3.8% annualized, accelerating and above expectations, suggesting inflation persistence despite weak job growth. This creates a disinflationary paradox: fewer workers being hired but those working earning more. Low hire, low fire environment leaves little margin for policy error if claims begin trending higher.

keyindicators.name: Unemployment Rate
keyindicators.implication: Labor market still tight, no major layoffs yet, but deterioration possible if hiring continues to collapse

keyindicators.name: Non-Farm Payrolls
keyindicators.implication: Job creation at 2020 recession levels, worst monthly reading in years, hiring recession dynamics

keyindicators.name: Jobless Claims
keyindicators.implication: No surge yet, but rising. Yellow flag if trend continues higher. 225K+ would signal deterioration acceleration

keyindicators.name: Wage Growth YoY
keyindicators.implication: Labor cost inflation above Fed comfort zone, constrains rate-cut frequency, supports demand but inflation concerns

keyindicators.name: 2025 Average Monthly Jobs
keyindicators.implication: Worst year for hiring since 2003 outside recession, represents hiring recession declaration

drivers: Seasonal early-January weakness in hiring typical, but magnitude exceeding norms by 35%+
Manufacturing contraction reducing industrial job creation directly, corporate realignment post-2024 gains
Tech sector rationalization stabilizing but at lower headcount baseline post-2024 hiring boom
Services and hospitality still hiring but at slower pace, retail weakening (-25K December)
risks: Non-farm payrolls decline further sustained 50K or below for 2 months unemployment rate rises above 5.0%
Household-establishment survey divergence resolves to downside: household survey also weakens, confirming breadth of labor softening
Jobless claims trend higher 225K+ sustained would signal deterioration acceleration and recession probability jump to 40%+
supports: Unemployment already improving 4.4% vs. prior 4.6%, no widespread layoff announcements, tech companies stabilizing headcount
Wage growth supports consumption household balance sheets remain strong, credit card delinquencies low
Low hire/low fire environment suggests corporates retaining workers despite weak demand

inflation.description: Inflation trajectory disinflationary heading into 2026. Core CPI and PCE expected to remain well-controlled as shelter costs cool and energy stabilizes. However, wage growth at 3.8% may provide floor on inflation, and sticky core services remain slight concern. Key binary catalyst: January 14, 2026 CPI print will be determinative for Fed messaging and equity market direction. Disinflationary print (Core CPI 0.2% MoM or lower) supports GROWTH path and signals soft-landing confirmation. Sticky print (Core CPI 0.3-0.4% MoM) sustains TRANSITION or shifts toward DEFENSIVE. Market pricing 35% bullish (disinflationary), 35% neutral, 30% bearish (sticky) probability.

keyindicators.name: Core CPI ex-food energy
keyindicators.implication: Core inflation cool, no sticky surprises yet

keyindicators.name: Shelter Costs
keyindicators.implication: Housing component normalizing after years of elevation, cooling trajectory intact

keyindicators.name: Energy Oil Prices
keyindicators.implication: No inflationary shock from commodities, geopolitical risks contained

keyindicators.name: Wage Growth YoY
keyindicators.implication: Labor cost inflation remains above comfort zone, provides floor on services inflation

drivers: Fed rate cuts 75 bps total in 2025 creating disinflationary backdrop
Energy stability no geopolitical oil shocks, pricing in soft landing
Shelter component cooling as rent growth moderates after multi-year surge
Wage growth sticky but not accelerating, suggests inflation stabilizing near current levels
risks: Wage acceleration surprises higher sticky core services inflation reaccelerating
Oil price shock or tariff-driven commodity inflation surprising higher
Shelter costs plateau before reaching 2% trend, sticky floor higher than expected
supports: Disinflationary trend established in Q4 2025, no reacceleration signals evident
Core CPI trajectory lower, January 14 CPI print expected disinflationary per Wall Street consensus
Fed cutting rates disinflationary bias, Powell signaling patience on rate path

financialconditions.indicator: Credit Spreads / VIX / Breadth / Yield Curve
financialconditions.description: Credit markets exceptionally tight, reflecting minimal systemic stress and strong credit demand. IG spreads at 79 bps tightest in 20 years. HY spreads at 279 bps also historically compressed, at 2nd percentile versus 20-year average of 521 bps. This means 1) No imminent credit stress or deleveraging risk, 2) Limited margin of safety if growth concerns mount sharply, 3) Spreads have little room to compress further, significant room to widen if macro deteriorates. VIX at 15.38 contained equity volatility no panic pricing. Yield curve steepening constructively (10Y-2Y slope 0.45%), supporting financial stability and easing conditions. Credit markets are giving the all-clear signal on systemic risk; current equity weakness is tactical profit-taking, rotation rather than structural credit crunch. Carry trade remains intact; leverage is not being forcibly unwound. NFCI National Financial Conditions Index at -0.55, easier than year ago, indicating safe-haven bid is about macro uncertainty rather than liquidity stress.

keyindicators.name: IG Credit Spreads
keyindicators.implication: Corporate credit demand strong, no stress signals, tightest in 20 years

keyindicators.name: HY Credit Spreads
keyindicators.implication: High-yield credit healthy, risk appetite intact, little room to compress

keyindicators.name: VIX Level
keyindicators.implication: Equity volatility contained, no panic pricing, calm surface despite event risk

keyindicators.name: Yield Curve Slope 10Y-2Y
keyindicators.implication: Growth-supportive curve shape, accommodative financial conditions, rate-cut expectations intact

keyindicators.name: NFCI National Financial Conditions Index
keyindicators.implication: Easier than year ago, safe-haven bid about macro uncertainty not liquidity stress

keyindicators.name: Bitcoin Carry-Trade Indicator
keyindicators.implication: Carry trade intact, high-beta risk appetite still broadly supported

drivers: Fed rate cuts 75 bps in 2025 reducing discount rates, easing financial conditions
Credit supply abundant no tightening in lending standards, corporate health strong
Equity market resilience driving risk appetite, rotation into value not panic de-risking
No major credit events or defaults, corporate earnings power remains intact
risks: Spreads widening sharply if growth data misses: IG spreads moving to 120 bps, HY to 350+ bps triggers reassessment
Credit event or default in leveraged corporate sector if recession probability spikes above 50%
Curve flattening if Fed signals pause on rate cuts, duration investors rotate out
supports: IG spreads tightest in 20 years indicate healthy credit cycle, no leverage unwind
HY spreads compressed, high-yield issuance strong, demand for corporate debt robust
VIX low equity volatility minimal, market pricing low stress environment
Curve steepening supports financial stability, rate-cut trajectory maintains easing bias

sectorrankings.rationale: Materials lead as rotation away from Mag7 concentration accelerates. Tariff dynamics and capex cycle turning supportive. Precious metals benefiting from safe-haven demand (gold +67% YoY). Leading sector in TRANSITION regime as breadth expansion favors cyclicals. Russell 2000 outperformance +5.1% this week validates rotation thesis.
keycatalysts: Tariff policy clarity expected this quarter, potential tailwind to commodity prices
Capex recovery in Q1 2026 infrastructure, defense spending unlocking demand
Gold-silver prices elevated, jewelry and industrial demand supporting base metals
Mining M&A activity accelerating as consolidation premium emerges
risks: Tariff reversal or commodity price collapse if trade tensions ease
Chinese demand weakness and capex slowdown if global growth disappoints
Environmental/ESG pressure on mining companies, regulatory costs rising

sectorrankings.rationale: Healthcare a reliable beneficiary of rate-cut environments lower discount rates boost valuation multiples. Defensive characteristics make it attractive in TRANSITION regime. Earnings cycle durable drug approvals steady pipeline. Aging population structural tailwind. Clinical breakthroughs in GLP-1 oral medications and biotech innovation driving fresh upside potential. Sector breadth strong with 8 of 11 sectors up, indicating genuine participation rather than narrow leadership.
keycatalysts: Rate-cut cycle continues, valuation expansion potential sustained
Q4 earnings season strength in biotech and medical devices (Jan 13-15 banking sector kickoff)
M&A activity consolidation premium emerging in undervalued subsectors
Aging population and GLP-1 oral adoption driving volume growth
risks: Drug pricing pressure from regulation, margin compression risk
R&D setbacks in key pipelines, patent cliff and generic competition
Excess PE valuation if rate-cut cycle pauses or reverses

sectorrankings.rationale: Utilities benefiting from AI data center build-out and nuclear power demand rising. Rate-cut cycle supports bond-like characteristics and dividend yield becomes increasingly attractive. Defensive positioning in TRANSITION regime with margin expansion from operational leverage. Nuclear expansion announcements and AI power demand create growth optionality often missed by traditional utility investors.
keycatalysts: Nuclear capacity expansion announcements AI data center power demands
Rate-cut cycle yield pickup attractive relative to alternatives
Dividend growth and share buyback programs supporting valuations
Renewable energy mandates creating growth optionality across substations and grid modernization
risks: Regulatory pressure on rate base capex and capex constraints limiting returns
Bond yields stabilize or rise, creating valuation pressure on rate-sensitive utilities
Nuclear cost overruns and construction delays if projects slip timelines

sectorrankings.rationale: Industrials benefiting from defense spending and infrastructure tailwinds. Earnings cycle supports moderate allocation. Less cyclical than Materials but more exposed to growth cycles than Utilities. Good fit for TRANSITION regime. Defense budget increases have bipartisan support providing durable tailwind. AI data center infrastructure capex benefits industrial equipment makers and installation services.
keycatalysts: Defense budget increases bipartisan support, multi-year programs locked in
Infrastructure investment programs, non-residential construction acceleration
Manufacturing stabilization in H1 2026 if ISM breaks above 48 and sustains
AI capex acceleration benefits industrial equipment and logistics
risks: Manufacturing contraction worsens, ISM breaks below 46 sustained signals recession
Capex cycle delays if recession concerns mount, corporate caution increases
Supply chain disruptions from geopolitical events, tariff volatility

sectorrankings.rationale: Financials benefit from steeper yield curve, net interest margins improve. Credit spreads tight (79 bps), low loan-loss provisions. Banking sector stabilized post-SVB, capital ratios elevated. Moderate allocation appropriate for TRANSITION regime. Q1 2026 earnings season starting Jan 13 should show strong results from NIM expansion and tight credit.
keycatalysts: Yield curve steepening continues, NIM expansion supports earnings
Q1 2026 earnings strength, bank capital returns accelerating (buybacks, dividends)
M&A activity rising, investment banking fees improving
Credit quality remains intact with low delinquencies supporting ROA
risks: Yield curve flattening if Fed reverses rate-cut pace, NIM pressure accelerates
Credit deterioration if labor market cracks and unemployment spikes above 5.0%
Regulatory changes to capital requirements imposing new constraints

sectorrankings.rationale: Consumer Discretionary neutral in TRANSITION regime. Household spending remains resilient but faces headwinds from wage growth moderation and job creation collapse. Retail earnings mixed, luxury goods (concentrated in Mag7) under pressure. Mid-tier discretionary more attractive than luxury. Valuation stretched relative to fundamentals. Sector participation is last in line of capital flows during rotation, suggesting opportunity emerges after Materials, Healthcare, Utilities exhaust upside.
keycatalysts: Holiday sales beat supporting Q4-Q1 earnings
Wage growth stabilization validates consumer strength thesis
Unemployment remains below 5.0%, job security supports spending
Credit card delinquencies remain low, consumer debt service manageable
risks: Consumer spending slowdown if labor market cracks, unemployment rises 5.0%+
Discount and promotional environment squeezing margins across retail
Housing market softness reducing wealth effect and consumer confidence
Credit card delinquencies rising if debt burden becomes unsustainable

sectorrankings.rationale: Real Estate lagging in TRANSITION regime. Office vacancy high, remote work structural headwind. Industrial REITs benefiting from e-commerce but retail REITs under pressure. Rate-cut cycle eventually helps (lower cap rates), but near-term pain from debt servicing and revaluations. No protective bid despite economic slowdown signals suggests market not yet in true defensive mode.
keycatalysts: Office-to-residential conversions creating supply reduction potential
Rate cuts boosting cap rates and providing valuation relief longer-term
Logistics REITs benefiting from e-commerce acceleration
Dividend yields attractive at current depressed valuation levels
risks: Office sector deterioration accelerates structural vacancy floor higher than expected
Debt refinancing pressure if rates stay elevated longer than market expects
Recession reducing occupancy rates across all property types
Cap rate expansion continuing if growth concerns persist, pushing valuations lower

sectorrankings.rationale: Consumer Staples defensive but underweighting due to high valuations relative to growth. Trading premium to market due to defensive characteristics in TRANSITION regime. Earnings growth modest, margin pressure from input costs possible. Better as defensive hedge than core position. Inflation in staples constrained by wage pressures but competition from private label remains intense.
keycatalysts: Inflation moderation supporting gross margin expansion
Commodity price stabilization in food and energy
Dividend growth and buyback programs stabilizing valuations
Online sales growth and channel diversification offsetting volume pressure
risks: Wage inflation hitting input costs faster than pricing power allows
Private-label competition intensifying, market share loss acceleration
Recession reducing trading-up demand, volume pressure from consumer
Tariff impact on imported goods raising cost structure

sectorrankings.rationale: Energy neutral in TRANSITION regime. Oil prices stable around $82/bbl, geopolitical risks contained. Refining margins healthy but facing peak earnings risk as crude input costs rise. LNG export growth supporting upstream valuations. Dividend yields attractive, buyback programs robust. Valuation reasonable but not compelling given macro uncertainty.
keycatalysts: Oil prices stable or higher on geopolitical support, demand resilience
OPEC production cuts extended, floor on pricing maintained
LNG export growth supporting energy security premiums
Dividend growth and share buyback programs sustaining returns
risks: Oil price collapse if geopolitical tensions ease or recession fears spike
Renewable energy acceleration creating stranded asset risk
Regulatory pressure on climate and emissions becoming more aggressive
Currency weakness impacting ExxonMobil, Chevron foreign earnings

sectorrankings.rationale: Communications Meta, Google, Magnificent Seven concentration under profit-taking pressure. Despite strong advertising fundamentals, valuations stretched, concentration risk elevated. YouTube, Instagram growth solid but facing competitive pressure from TikTok, short-form video. Regulatory risk persistent across antitrust and content moderation. Sector divergence: Meta showing +1.1% this week while GOOG +0.9%, but both facing structural headwinds. AAPL -4.2% this week highlights Mag7 repricing underway.
keycatalysts: AI monetization in search and advertising improvements
Q4 earnings beat on holiday ad spending supporting momentum
Cloud revenue growth acceleration in enterprise AI services
Capex discipline reducing margin expansion near-term but supporting optionality
risks: Advertising recession if consumer spending slows materially
Regulatory antitrust action against Google, Meta structurally damaging
AI training cost explosion compressing margins as capex accelerates
TikTok ban or restrictions creating competition void but also regulatory risk

sectorrankings.rationale: Technology severely concentrated in Magnificent Seven NVDA, MSFT, GOOGL, AMZN, TSLA, META, AVGO, which are experiencing profit-taking after dominant 2024. Concentration at 34.4% of SP500 market cap (down from peak 35%+, approaching caution threshold of 35%). Cap-weighted sector performance +18.2% YTD masks breadth weakness: equal-weight performance only +6.9%. Only 7 stocks driving majority of sector returns. TRANSITION regime does not favor concentrated tech growth. AI narrative intact for infrastructure plays (MSFT, AMZN, GOOG) but repricing for speculative names (AAPL -4.2%, TSLA timeline slippage, NVDA valuation reset). Market discrimination between substance (core AI infra) and hype (speculative AI) is working.
keycatalysts: AI capex cycle peak concern, potential saturation in 2026 if guidance disappoints
Q4 2025 earnings and forward guidance critical: MSFT Azure 40% YoY beats, AMZN AWS 20% reaccel, GOOG capex 85B commitment
Tablet PC refresh cycles demand shift potential as aging devices replace
Cloud adoption acceleration and recurring revenue model strengthening valuations for quality
risks: Valuation reset and compression if growth disappoints Q4 earnings
Magnificent Seven concentration reversal driving breadth rotation continuation
Regulatory antitrust action against AAPL, GOOG, META, AMZN structurally damaging
AI capex intensity rising, margin pressure ahead as costs accelerate
sectorrankings.safehavennote: Magnificent Seven Mag7 core NVDA, MSFT, GOOGL, AMZN, TSLA should be held for quality and optionality but reduced on strength given valuation stretched positioning. Mag7 concentration at 34.4% (per Jan 10 data) warrants systematic trimming as rotation into Materials, Healthcare, Utilities continues. Core AI infrastructure (MSFT +0.2%, AMZN +0.4%, GOOG +0.9%) showing resilience while speculative AI (AAPL -4.2%, TSLA timeline delays, NVDA -2.1% valuation reset) repricing lower. This is healthy market differentiation, NOT panic unwinding. Breadth expansion (66% SP500 above 200d MA, Russell 2000 +5.1% this week) validates rotation thesis. Strategic positioning: maintain 50% Mag7 weighted toward MSFT/AMZN/GOOG core AI infrastructure, 50% non-Mag7 quality to hedge concentration risk.

stockanalystguidance.convictionadjustment: Reduce cyclical conviction by 8pp; reduce growth-tech conviction by 12pp; boost defensive conviction by 5pp; boost value conviction by 8pp.

sizehintadjustments.growthstocks: Cap at 4% max position size vs normal 6%; conviction threshold 75pp vs normal 70pp
sizehintadjustments.cyclicalstocks: Normal 6% max; conviction threshold 75pp vs 70pp; require strong Materials/Industrials thesis
sizehintadjustments.defensivestocks: Allow 6% max (vs normal 5%); conviction threshold 65pp vs 70pp; Healthcare/Utilities favorable
sizehintadjustments.valuestocks: Encourage 6% max allocations; conviction threshold 70pp (normal); Materials/Financials sweet spot

stockanalystguidance.exampleapplication: Tesla (growth-tech cyclical): Base conviction 78pp. TRANSITION regime penalty -12pp = 66pp conviction (MEDIUM-LOW). Position capped at 4%. Caterpillar (Materials cyclical): Base conviction 72pp. TRANSITION regime boost 8pp = 80pp conviction (MEDIUM-HIGH). Position sized normally 6%.

actionpriorities.action: OVERWEIGHT Materials sector from 5% to 10% equity allocation
actionpriorities.rationale: Materials rank 1 attractiveness (89/100), leading rotation away from Mag7 concentration. Tariff upside, capex cycle turning positive, precious metals benefiting from safe-haven demand. Russell 2000 +5.1% this week validates cyclical opportunity.

actionpriorities.action: OVERWEIGHT Healthcare sector from 10% to 14% equity allocation
actionpriorities.rationale: Healthcare rank 2 attractiveness (85/100), defensive rate-cut beneficiary, earnings durable, aging population structural tailwind. GLP-1 oral medications and biotech innovation driving fresh upside. Q4 earnings season strength (Jan 13-15) should accelerate rotation.

actionpriorities.action: OVERWEIGHT Utilities sector from 6% to 10% equity allocation
actionpriorities.rationale: Utilities rank 3 attractiveness (82/100), AI data center nuclear power demand rising, rate-cut cycle supports dividend yield, operational leverage margin expansion. Emerging growth optionality often overlooked by traditional allocators.

actionpriorities.action: REDUCE Technology sector from 20% to 12-15% equity allocation
actionpriorities.rationale: Technology rank 11 attractiveness (48/100), Mag7 concentration 34.4% at caution threshold. AAPL -4.2% this week, NVDA valuation reset, TSLA timeline slippage signal repricing underway. Market discriminating between core AI infrastructure (resilient) and speculative AI (repricing lower).

actionpriorities.action: TRIM Magnificent Seven holdings, reduce by 25% on 5%+ strength
actionpriorities.rationale: Mag7 concentration 34.4% vs normal 20% represents systemic concentration risk. Strategic trimming on strength generates proceeds for rotation into Materials, Healthcare, Utilities. Breadth expansion validates rotation as healthy, not panic-driven.

deploymenttriggers.action: Deploy 3% of cash reserves into Materials/Healthcare on weakness
Maintain position, continue systematic Mag7 trimming
Deploy 5% cash into quality large-cap on panic

hedgingplan.vixcallsootm: Maintain 2% portfolio allocation in 3-month OTM VIX calls for tail-risk protection
hedgingplan.goldsilverallocation: Maintain 3% portfolio allocation in precious metals for safe-haven hedge
hedgingplan.durationpositioning: Neutral; yield curve steepening supports duration-neutral stance, not aggressive long
hedgingplan.putspreadoverlay: Optional establish put spreads on Materials/Utilities high conviction sectors to reduce volatility

alphapicksanalystguidance.convictionadjustmentrule: In TRANSITION regime, apply -8pp to all growth-tech positions; apply 8pp to Materials, Healthcare, Utilities positions; apply 0pp to quality cyclicals.
alphapicksanalystguidance.capconcentration: No single position >5% to avoid Mag7-style concentration risk

candidatescreeningrules.rule: Prefer Materials sector candidates, ISM weakness creates capex cycle opportunity
candidatescreeningrules.examples: FCX, NUE, DD diversified materials with capex tailwind

candidatescreeningrules.rule: Prefer Healthcare candidates with earnings visibility
candidatescreeningrules.examples: UNH, JNJ, LLY quality healthcare names beating Q4 earnings
NEE, SO, AES renewables and nuclear positioning

candidatescreeningrules.rationale: Concentration risk unwarranted in TRANSITION regime

candidatescreeningrules.rule: Avoid growth-tech unless thesis very strong (conviction 80+)
candidatescreeningrules.examples: ASML, NVDA, META below 80pp conviction UNDERWEIGHT

autooverridetriggers.action: Auto-shift to DEFENSIVE constraints: 45% equity, 40% bonds, 15% cash/hedges
autooverridetriggers.rationale: Elevated recession risk warrants capital preservation

autooverridetriggers.condition: If breadth reversal confirmed (A/D <0.60 for 3 consecutive days)
autooverridetriggers.action: Auto-execute 10% equity trim, shift proceeds to bonds/cash
autooverridetriggers.rationale: Breadth reversal signals regime shift to defensive

autooverridetriggers.condition: If VIX closes above 25 for 2 consecutive days
autooverridetriggers.rationale: VIX >25 elevated volatility requiring immediate response

sectorcapguidance.rationale: TRANSITION regime supports cap increases for Materials/Healthcare/Utilities, decreases for Tech/Communications

positionsizingfinal.breadthrequirement: Ensure 50+ stocks represent 70% of equity returns vs current concentration

keywatchitems.threshold: Core CPI 0.2% MoM or lower, 2.7% YoY or lower
keywatchitems.condition: If CPI comes in disinflationary, soft landing confirmed
keywatchitems.marketresponse: Tech profit-taking reversal, Mag7 resumes upside, small-cap weakness reverses, VIX compresses further

keywatchitems.threshold: Powell signals patient stance on rate cuts, no hawkish pivot
keywatchitems.condition: If Powell/Fed signals comfort with rate-cut continuation
keywatchitems.marketresponse: Equity risk premium compresses, PE multiple expansion begins, Bonds sell off, rates steepen then flatten

keywatchitems.threshold: ISM PMI 49+ for February report (Jan reading 47.9)
keywatchitems.condition: If ISM rebounds above 49 Jan report 50+, manufacturing streak broken
keywatchitems.marketresponse: Cyclical outperformance accelerates Materials, Industrials rotate higher, rate-cut momentum builds

keywatchitems.threshold: Tech earnings beat, Mag7 forward guidance upbeat 2026 growth 15%+
keywatchitems.condition: If Q4 earnings beat and Mag7 provides strong 2026 guidance
keywatchitems.marketresponse: Tech multiple re-rating upward, Mag7 resumes leadership, concentration risk returns

keywatchitems.threshold: Core CPI 0.4% MoM or higher, 3.1% YoY or higher
keywatchitems.condition: If CPI disappoints with sticky inflation, Fed pivot postponed, rate cuts delayed or reversed
keywatchitems.marketresponse: Equity selloff 3-5%, Bonds extend selloff, rates spike 30-50 bps, Gold rallies, Materials correction

keywatchitems.threshold: Non-farm payrolls 50K sustained for 2 months, unemployment 5.0%+
keywatchitems.condition: If labor market cracks, payroll 50K sustained, unemployment rising
keywatchitems.marketresponse: Equity selloff 5-10%, Flight-to-safety bonds/gold, VIX spikes 25+, credit spreads widen 50 bps

keywatchitems.threshold: ISM PMI 46 or below sustained, production and orders both contracting 3+ points MoM
keywatchitems.condition: If ISM breaks below 46 (11th+ consecutive contraction month)
keywatchitems.marketresponse: Cyclical -10% Materials, Industrials capitulate, Treasuries rally 50 bps yield drop, VIX 25+, equity selloff

keywatchitems.threshold: IG spreads widen to 150+ bps, HY spreads spike to 450+ bps
keywatchitems.condition: If credit spreads blow out 50+ bps from current tights
keywatchitems.marketresponse: Equity panic selling, deleveraging cascade, flight-to-Treasuries/gold, forced position liquidations

keywatchitems.threshold: Advance-decline ratio drops below 0.50, new highs-lows invert
keywatchitems.marketresponse: Equity breadth collapse, Mag7 weakness spreads to broader market, volatility spike, rotation reversal

ismmanufacturingpmi.impact: High relevance ISM stable but deteriorating trend, minor degradation if next report shows material change

nonfarmpayrolls.impact: VERYHIGH relevance, latest labor market snapshot near real-time analysis quality

unemploymentrate.impact: HIGH relevance, current labor market conditions near real-time analysis quality

creditspreads.impact: VERYHIGH relevance, real-time credit market sentiment, current stress assessment

marketbreadth.impact: VERYHIGH relevance, same-day market structure data, rotation validation current

cpidatamostrecent.impact: MEDIUM impact January 14 report expected 4 days out, current data used may be superseded

datafreshnessaudit.analysisnote: Data freshness is exceptional for regime classification. ISM manufacturing 24 hours old (preferred window met). Labor data fresh 20 hours old. Credit spreads very fresh (1 hour old). Market breadth updated intraweek (1 hour old). CPI data aged at 168 hours but acceptable pending Jan 14 report. Weekly Market Structure Report, Risk Regime Report, and AI/Mag7 Intelligence reports all dated January 10, 2026, incorporating Friday Jan 10 market close data. Overall freshness supports TRANSITION regime confidence 74% with minimal penalty.

regimes.reportcontext: Week 1 of 2026 analysis. Rotation from Mag7 concentration toward breadth participation confirmed. ISM manufacturing contraction in 10th month. Labor market hiring collapse (50K jobs December, weakest in years). Credit spreads tightest in 20 years, no systemic stress. Breadth expansion validates regime transition.
